text.p: Two late penalties, both converted by Johannes Hindjou, gave Namibia a dramatic 2-1 extra time win over Zimbabwe in the COSAFA Cup first round on Sunday.
The victory put Namibia into the final round group competition of the new southern African regional tournament, organised by the Confederation of Southern African Football Associations.
Trailing by a goal with just three minutes left, Namibia won a late reprieve with a penalty in the 87th minute when Zimbabwean defender Dumisani Mpofu handled.
Hindjou's first penalty sent the game into extra time where both teams launched furious, but tired, onslaughts on their opponents' goal.
Another handball by a Zimbabwean defender, this time Chamu Musanhu, gave Namibia a second penalty in the last minute. Hindjou converted for a remarkable victory.
It was the first time an encounter between two African national teams had been decided on the new "golden goal" rule and the result stretched Namibia's unbeaten home run to 10 matches.
They now join Malawi, Mozambique, Tanzania and Zambia in the group competition, which kicks off next month.
Namibia barely deserved to win against a more organised Zimabwean side, who had to do without their considerable foreign-based contingent.
New cap Gilbert Mushangashika had Zimbabwe ahead with 15 minutes left before Namibia stole the result away from them.
Mushangashika, recently returned from a spell in the German third division, also scored from the penalty spot after a clumsy challenge by Petrus Haraseb on Calistus Pasuwa.
The loss for Zimbabwe puts added pressure on Scottish coach Ian Porterfield, who has now lost two matches since taking over the team in November.
The draw for the Cosafa Castle Cup group matches was due to be made later on Sunday.
